title: Latest News from Science Magazine
description: Keyword search result for Alerts: News Weekly Headlines -- New results matching your keyword search query (updated daily).

items.title: That’s no spider! It’s a decoy
items.description: Arachnids build large lookalikes to ward off predators

items.title: Canadian government kills ostriches afflicted by H5N1 despite appeal from RFK Jr.
items.description: Culling proceeds after Canada’s Supreme Court ends heated 11-month battle over the fate of more than 300 birds

items.title: Sand mining threatens Asia’s largest lake
items.description: Cambodia’s Tonlé Sap supports important fisheries and wildlife

items.title: The twisted secret behind a chameleon’s oddball eyes
items.description: Coiled nerves allow the reptiles to move their peepers in multiple directions at once without moving their heads

items.title: James Watson: Titan of science with tragic flaws
items.description: Science historian Nathaniel Comfort reflects on the “most famous scientist of the 20th century, and the most infamous of the 21st”

items.title: Dementia researchers cheer Texas voters’ approval of $3 billion funding initiative
items.description: New effort is modeled after the state’s long-running cancer research institute

items.title: Metal scaffolds turn bacteria into live wires
items.description: Mud-dwelling cable bacteria construct metal organic frameworks to grow

items.title: Biologist David Sabatini loses again in legal fight against Whitehead Institute
items.description: Judge dismisses final claim against scientist’s former employer and curtails lawsuit directed at woman who accused him of sexual harassment

items.title: U.S. Congress considers sweeping ban on Chinese collaborations
items.description: Researchers speak out against proposal that would bar funding for U.S. scientists working with Chinese partners or training Chinese students

items.title: How politicians soured on one of Europe’s biggest primate research centers
items.description: Some scientists hope animal work at the Biomedical Primate Research Centre can continue despite vote by Dutch Parliament to end the studies
